metadata.title: Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized carbon nanotubes supported Pt-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde

Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized carbon nanotubes supported Pt-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde Zhengbin Tian Chao Liu Qingyang Li Juying Hou Yan Li ⁎ Shiyun Ai ⁎ College of Chemistry and Material Science, Shandong Agricultural University, 271018, PR China College of Chemistry and Material Science Shandong Agricultural University 271018 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: 271018, Daizong Street 61, Taian, Shandong, PR China. Fax: +86 538 8247660. Graphical abstract Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) supported Pt catalysts were employed to study the influence of nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized surface on catalytic performance in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized CNTs were simply treated with the hydrothermal method using ammonia and hydrogen peroxide, respectively, and the metal catalyst was prepared using an impregnation-reduction-deposition method. Here, we studied and gave some insights into the influence of the functionalization on CNTs surface chemistry environment and Pt nanoparticles using XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TEM, XPS, and nitrogen sorption techniques. It was shown that the functionalization lead to the small size distribution of Pt particles and promoted the conversion from ca. 75% to ca. 95%. To obtain the high selectivity, transition metals, cobalt and nickel, were doped into the Pt catalyst and the 99.7% conversion with the 87.9% selectivity was achieved over the nitrogen-functionalized CNTs supported PtCo catalysts. The PtCo/N-CNTs remained high activity even at 40°C and achieved 94.2% conversion and 90.3% selectivity. Keywords Functionalized Carbon nanotubes Cinnamaldehyde Selective hydrogenation 1 Introduction Cinnamaldehyde (CAL) is a particularly important representative of α, β-unsaturated aldehyde that contains two unsaturated bonds the carbonyl (CO) and olefinic (CC) group in molecule. The hydrogenation of CAL can generate different products, the partial one of which, cinnamyl alcohol (COL), is important intermediates in pharmaceutical and fragrance industries [1,2]. Also, it is considered as a good model for investing the catalytic behaviors of the microstructures of heterogeneous catalysts. The selective hydrogenation is a rather complex reaction network involving several important intermediates and a number of series-parallel reactions. The main competitive products of selective hydrogenation can be produced through the hydrogenation of the conjugated CC or CO bond over the supported metal catalysts. However, obtaining the unsaturated alcohols is difficult, owing to the fact that C&9552;O bond presents a higher binding energy than C&9552;C bond (715kJ/mol and 615kJ/mol, respectively) [3], the reduction of the C&9552;C bond is thermodynamically more favorable than that of CO bond. The selectivity to the unsaturated alcohol can be correlated with the metal D-banD width. Generally, the larger the d-band, the stronger the repulsive four-electron interaction of the metal with the CC double bond and the stronger the attractive interaction of the metal surface with the CO π-system, which results in good selectivity to the unsaturated alcohol (Ir, Os>Pt>Ru>Rh>Pd) [4]. Although various kinds of metal (Pd, Ru and Au)-based catalysts were employed in the hydrogenation reaction [5–7], Pt was most commonly used for the purpose of CO hydrogenations in fact. Maintaining high selectivity of Pt-based catalysts while increasing their activity remains an urgent task for further development in this field. Many studies have been devoted to enhance the selectivity towards the unsaturated alcohol either by fine control of the sizes [8] and/or the exposed facets of the active metal nanoparticles [9], or by exploiting the steric constraints imposed by the environment of the active site [10], or by decorating the primary metal with a second metal component [11], or by adding promoters like an alkali element [1]. However, most methods usually involved ingenious design and complex process. Therefore, searching for appropriate materials used as supports is a simple and feasible way to prepare highly active and selective catalysts for the hydrogenation reaction. The conventional carbon nanostructure materials, especially carbon nanotubes (CNTs), have been widely employed as support in heterogeneous catalysis, owing to the high electrical conductivity and corrosion resistance [12]. Their high surface area could lead to a high dispersion of metal nanoparticles and the perfect smooth graphitic surface could make all metal nanoparticles on CNTs accessible to the reactants. Additionally, the transfer of π-electrons from the graphitic planes of CNTs to the metal particles leads to the increase in the charge density on the metal, which decreases the probability of CC bond activation and favors the formation of unsaturated alcohols [13,14]. Recently, functionalized or doped CNTs are considered as one of the promising supports due to the merits performing in the catalytic process. The functionalization mainly focuses on two aspects, nitrogen and oxygen. The functionalization treatments have excited chemists to renovate traditional catalysis materials and, actually, it has been proved that they could significantly improve CNTs interaction with solvents and dispersion, allow the grafting of nanoparticles [15,16] and promote the adsorption of energy molecules and modulate molecular reactivity and selectivity [17,18]. Chizari et al. prepared N-doped CNTs (synthesized using a Chemical Vapor Deposition process) supported Pd catalyst and investigated the influence of different types of incorporated nitrogen species on the liquid-phase hydrogenation of CAL [19]. Solhy et al. reported three activation procedures of Multi-walled CNTs: nitric acid oxidation, ball-milling and air oxidation and its influence on the catalytic performance of Pt/MWCNT catalysts for selective hydrogenation [20]. However, the different influence of nitrogen and oxygen species on the catalytic performance has been not researched. Here, nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized CNTs were simply obtained with the hydrothermal method using ammonia and hydrogen peroxide, respectively. Pt-based catalyst supported on those nanotubes was prepared with the traditional impregnation-reduction-deposition method. The main aim of the present work was to study and compare the effects of oxygen and nitrogen species on the CNTs surface chemistry environment and Pt-based nanoparticles, and to evaluate the influence of the functionalization on the catalytic performances of Pt-based catalysts for selective hydrogenation. The functionalized CNTs and prepared Pt-based catalysts were fully characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), nitrogen sorption isotherms and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques. The performances of different Pt-based catalysts were investigated and compared under mild reaction conditions. We found that the high conversion and selectivity could be achieved over the nitrogen-functionalized CNTs supported PtCo catalysts even at the room temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals Multi-walled CNTs prepared by the chemical vapor deposition method with Fe-Co/Al2O3 as catalyst were obtained from Boyu Gaoke New Material Technology Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China). All reagents used in the experiment were analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. H2PtCl6·6H2O, CoCl2·H2O, CAL and NaBH4 were purchased from Aladdin. Ammonia, hydrogen peroxide (30%) and concentrated HCl (12mol/L) were purchased from Kangde Chemical Reagent (Yantai, China). Ethanol was purchased from Yongda Chemical Reagent (Tianjin, China). Distilled deionized water was utilized through the experiments. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Prior to functionalization, the pristine CNTs were refluxed in 6M NaOH and 6M HCl aqueous solution at 110°C for 6h, respectively, in turn to remove catalysts. The purified CNTs were thoroughly washed with distilled water until the filtrate was neutral, and then dried at 70°C overnight. A typical surface functionalization procedure of CNTs is described as follows: 2g purified CNTs and 60mL ammonia was placed into a 100mL Teflon-vessel, which was sealed in the autoclave subsequently, and then moved to the autoclave for steaming at the temperature of 180°C. After the steaming treatment for 12h, the autoclave was cooled down to the room temperature and the nitrogen-functionalized CNTs (N-CNTs) was obtained and thoroughly washed with distilled water. The oxygen-functionalized CNTs (O-CNTs) were obtained though the same method with hydrogen peroxide as the functionalization reagent instead. The Pt/CNTs catalyst was prepared using an impregnation-reduction-deposition method. The CNTs support was impregnated in aqueous solution of and H2PtCl6 at 80°C for 5h in a round-bottom flask. Then, 20mL of 0.1mol/L NaBH4 solution was subsequently added dropwise to the flask under vigorous stirring for another 1h. Filter the slurry and wash the solid with water until filtrate is neutral, then dry the solid at 50°C under vacuum for 12h. The nominal content of Pt in the catalyst was 2wt.%. The PtCo and PtNi bimetallic catalyst was prepared using the same method with nominal Pt and content of 1wt.%, respectively. 2.3 Characterization XRD patterns were measured at room temperature by using a D8 Advance (Bruker, Germany) X-ray diffractometer with the Cu Kα radiation at 40kV and 30mA. Raman spectra of samples were collected from 200 to 2000cm−1 on a LabRAM HR800 Laser Confocal Micro-Raman Spectroscopy (Horiba Jobin Yvon, Japan) using a 532nm laser source. TEM was characterized by a by a FEI Tecnai G20 (USA) with an accelerating voltage of 200kV. The textural properties of samples were performed by nitrogen sorption isotherms on an ASAP 3020 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) at 77K. The surface area and pore volume were calculated using BET and BJH methods, respectively. XPS was measured with a K-Alpha XPS system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) using a monochromatic Al Kα as the excitation source (1486.6eV). Survey (wide) scans spanned from 1000 to 0eV binding energy, which were collected with an analyzer pass energy of 100eV at an interval of 1.00eV. 2.4 Hydrogenation reaction The hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a stainless autoclave reactor with a 50mL Teflon sleeve. In a typical procedure, 0.1g catalyst was dispersed in 19mL ethanol and then 8.2 mmol CAL was added into solution. The reactor was sealed, purging with H2 for 3 times, respectively, and then pressurized to 2.0MPa. The reaction was conducted at 70°C with a stirring speed of 750rpm for 2h. The reaction mixture was analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2010 gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID) system equipped with a capillary column SE-54 [(5%-phenyl)-95%dimethylpolysiloxane, 30m×0.32mm×0.5μm]. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Fig. 1 a shows the powder XRD patterns of as-prepared catalysts. The peaks at 26.1°, 43.5°, 54.1°, 77.5° were attributed to the (002), (101), (004) and (110) diffractions of hexagonal graphitic carbon (JCPDS 41-1487), respectively. The wide (002) peak showed that the CNTs possess amorphous structure with small regions of crystallinity and the regions of crystallinity are highly graphitic [21]. The position and sharpness of the C (002) peak in the Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs indicates that the graphite structure of the CNTs was functionalized without significant damage. The lattice structure (d) of region of crystallization was maintained well after the functionalization. A puzzling phenomenon was observed that the two treated samples had a broader full width at half maximum (FWHM) which was related to crystallite size, implying that the treatment damaged the ordered crystal structure, resulting in a decrease in crystallite size. This is also proved through the Raman spectroscopy. The broad diffraction peaks at 40.2°, 46.4° and 68.2° in good agreement with the metallic platinum (111), (200), and (220) reflections (JCPDS card No. 04-0802), could be observed in the Pt/CNT sample, which were consistent with the face-centered cubic (fcc) structure of platinum [22]. However, the peaks disappeared in the Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs due to the smaller crystallite size of Pt, indicating functionalized CNTs support favor the dispersion of metal nanoparticles. When the crystallite size was less than 5nm, the two adjacent peaks Pt(111) and Pt(200) will broaden and overlap each other in amplitude rather than intensity, which would lead to the weakening even disappearance in peaks. Raman spectroscopy was employed to characterize carbonaceous materials for distinguishing ordered and disordered crystal structures. All the materials in the Fig. 1b had same peak positions of the G band (1576cm−1), assigned to Raman-active E2g mode for the tangential in-plane stretching vibrations of the sp2-hybridized bonds, the D band (1326cm−1), corresponding to the breakdown of translational symmetry produced by the microcrystalline structure, and D'-band (1612cm−1), attributed to a double-resonance Raman feature induced by disorder, defects or ion intercalation between the graphitic walls [23]. After the functionalization, the N and O element was doped into the ordered crystal structure of CNTs. Therefore the lattice defect obviously increased and the D band became strong for N-CNTs and N-CNTs. Typically, The ratio of the integral intensities of the G and D bands (ID/IG) is used to probe the degree of graphitization [24] and the in-plane crystallite size (equation: L a =(2.4×10−10)λ 4 laser( I D/I G)−1) [25] of samples. Among the three samples, Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs have the higher I D/I G value than Pt/CNTs and so they have the lower degree of graphitization and smaller crystallite size, which is consistent with XRD. Fig. 2 shows the TEM photographs and the corresponding histograms of the particle size distribution of Pt NPs on the CNTs, respectively. There was no obvious difference in the terms of morphology and all the catalysts presented regular mesochannels with the external diameter averaged 13nm and inner diameter of 3.6nm. It was observed that Pt NPs were highly dispersed on the support with a narrow sizes distribution ranging from 2 to 6nm, regardless of the types of support. This was because NaBH4 reduction was able to produce small and uniform metal particles [26]. However, the maximum of Pt sizes present a slight difference for these catalysts. The main Pt sizes in Pt/CNTs concentrated on 4-4.5nm with a mean size of 4.3nm. The Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs catalyst had smaller Pt NPs with a mean size of 3.7nm and 3.9nm, respectively. This result strongly suggested that the final particle size distribution of Pt was dominated by the interaction between Pt and the functionalized support surface. Most of the Pt NPs were located on the external wall of CNTs, while a portion of the Pt NPs with a small size were selectively present with a light color at the inner wall in the Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/N-CNTs. Due to the limit of the CNTs channels, the large Pt NPs could not enter into the pores and were forced to locate on the external surface of the support, while the small ones could enter and locate on the inner wall. This phenomenon shows that the confinement effect also plays a minor role in affecting the size distribution of Pt particles. The porosity and surface area of the different catalysts were characterized by N2 sorption measurements. All the samples exhibit mixed isotherm of type II (at high p/p0) and type IV adsorption (at lower p/p0) with H3-type hysteresis loop in the relative pressure region of 0.85–1.0, indicating the existence of plenty of mesopores in the catalyst. The surface area, pore volume and pore diameter calculated from the N2 sorption isotherm are tabulated in the Table 1 . It can been seen from the Table 1 that the similar date of BET surface area and BJH surface area was observed and mesopores volume was dominant in the total pore volume. Obviously, the functionalized presented an increase in the surface area, pore volume and pore diameter. This would promote the effective exposure of active sites in the catalyst, resulting in the improvement of catalytic activity (Fig. 3 ). XPS was used to investigate the elemental composition, chemical state and electronic state of the elements existed in catalysts. On the basis of the XPS analyses, it was found that the three catalysts were composed of C, O, N, Pt elements and the element content was tabulated in the Table 2 . The inherent existence of N and O elements was detected in the Pt/CNTs, which may come from the prepared process of CNTs and the molecular N2 and O2 absorbed on the surface. Fig. 4 a reveals the C1s spectrum, which was composed of the major sp2C fraction of carbon species, sp3 hybridized C and minor contribution from different bonding configurations of carbon with inherent oxygen or nitrogen. There is no obvious difference among the C1s spectrum, but a hump around 291.5eV in the ammonia and hydrogen peroxide functionalized catalyst, respectively, demonstrating that the carbon matrix was chemically modified with nitrogen- or oxygen-containing functional groups. The High-resolution N1s spectra of Pt/N-CNTs are shown in Fig. 4b and was deconvoluted into three types: 398.9±0.1, 400.4±0.2, and 401.2±0.1, corresponding to the pyridinic N (N1), pyrrolic N (N2), and N-H (N3) with relative percentage of 28.6, 57.1 and 14.3% [27–29]. From an oxygen deconvolution curve (Fig. 4c), the oxygen spectrum can be well-resolved to three peaks with binding energies at 531.9±0.2, 533.1±0.1, and 534.1±0.1eV assigned to C O (O1), COC (O2), and COH (O3) species [28,30]. The corresponding relative percentage of three peaks is 44.7, 32.8 and 22.5%, respectively. In comparison with the N and O spectrum in the Pt/CNTs (Fig. S2), the N3-type nitrogen and O3-type oxygen in the functionalized catalyst increased obviously and the changes of the others were irregular. Although the details of the surface chemistry occurring during NH3 and H2O2 functionalization remain elusive, these changes clearly suggested that the NH3 and H2O2 functionalization not merely increased the density of the N and O element but also dramatically modified its surface functional groups, both of which were crucial for enhancing the catalytic activity. From the Table 2, the surface content of Pt in the Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs was higher than that in the Pt/CNTs. This was most due to the interaction between PtCl2- 6and the functional groups on the surface of N-CNTs and O-CNTs. Tuaev et al. [31] had proved that the doped nitrogen had the stabilizing effect on Pt nanoparticles and mediated the enhancement of platinum adsorption on the surface of carbon materials. Through the interaction, the metal ions were adsorbed on the surface of support and reduced in the process of catalyst preparation, which undoubtedly improved the content and dispersion of metal nanoparticles in catalyst. Fig. 4d–f presented the Pt4f spectra of obtained catalysts, which could be deconvoluted into three pairs of doublets attributed to zerovalent Pt(0), Pt(II) and Pt(IV) species. The interval of binding energy between the doublets was around 3.5eV and the ratio of integral peak area of Pt4f7/2 to Pt4f5/2 was close to a value of 4: 3. The most intense doublet was attributed to metallic Pt, but the weakest peaks could be assigned to the Pt(IV) species such as PtO2 [5,32]. The third pair of peaks was most likely ascribed to Pt(II) chemical state as in either PtO or Pt(OH)2 [1,33]. The binding energy and relative concentration for Pt species are summarized in Table 2. The binding energy of Pt is affected by the functionalization agent. A shift of ca. 0.5eV and 0.2eV toward high binding energy for Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs were observed as compared with Pt/CNTs. The observable shift of the binding energy of Pt4f confirmed there mostly was an electron transfer between Pt and amino and oxygen groups in the Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs catalysts, which was similarly observed in Pt NPs supported on polypyrrole carbon black [34]. The distribution of Pt(0), Pt(II) and Pt(IV) species is similar for the Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs catalysts studied, but the obvious difference was that the content of Pt(II) and Pt(IV) was much higher than that in the Pt/CNTs. 3.2 Catalytic test The hydrogenation of CAL typically produced a mixture of the desired COL and the undesired products. Fig. 5 illustrated the reaction pathways in hydrogenation of CAL. The hydrogenation in C&9552;O bond can form COL while the hydrogenation in CC bond leaded to the formation of HCAL. Further hydrogenation of these two inter-mediates resulted in the formation of hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCOL). Aldol condensation of acetal (ACE) and other unidentified products may be produced in small amounts particularly over nonselective catalysts [35]. Different CNTs supported Pt catalysts were tested for the selective hydrogenation of CAL under the same mild conditions for the investigation of the support effect and time effect. Fig. 6 shows the variation of CAL conversion and product selectivity as a function of reaction time for Pt/CNTs, Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6, the reaction time sharply influenced the conversion of CAL, but had little effect on selectivity for Pt/CNTs catalyst. The conversion of CAL reached 93.7% over Pt/N-CNTs catalyst after reaction for 1.5h; in comparison, only 82.7% conversion was obtained over Pt/CNTs catalyst after reaction for 2.5h. It was observed that the conversion of CAL reached 90.8% over Pt/O-CNTs catalyst after reaction just for 1.0h. It is obviously the activity of Pt/N-CNT was lower than that of Pt/O-CNT in the same reaction conditions. No significant selectivity change was found on Pt/N-CNTs and Pt/O-CNT in the reaction time before 2h. However, the amount of HCOL increased sharply after reaction for 1.5h. Extending reaction time improved the equivalent opportunity that hydrogen molecules accessed to the CC and CO in the reaction medium, which resulted in an increase in conversion and a stable selectivity. However, as the reaction time was extended, the increased concentration of CAL and COL leaded to the further hydrogenation and caused a sharp increase in HCOL especially over Pt/CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs. The presence of the functionalization, especially for oxygen-functionalization, in the final catalyst was detrimental to the selective hydrogenation of CAL to COL in long reaction time. Though the COL selectivity was not changed, the catalytic activity in terms of conversion was enhanced greatly over Pt/CNTs and Pt/O-CNTs. The enhancement was related to the high Pt content and smaller Pt NPs size without a doubt. Specially, the attendance of high content of reducible Pt species, like PtO and PtO2 was generally considered to improve the catalytic activity. That was because there was a strong interaction between the carbonyl group and positively charged center (PtO δ+ x ) [36]. Although the high conversion was achieved, some measures need to be performed due to the poor selectivity. Transition metals have been employed widely as co-catalysts in large variety of hydrogenation reactions. The selectivity and the activity of the catalysts could be considerably modulated by combining a transition metal with Pt metals [31], because the differences in the lattice constants between Pt and 3d transition metals can lead to the formation of strained PtM bimetallic structures [11]. The compact lattice surface prefers the adsorption of the CO bond, due to the steric effect. The adsorption of the CC bond is substituted and thus hindered. Nevertheless, the open lattice cannot hindered CC bond adsorption and then multiplies the chances for CC bond contacting with metal nanoparticles compared with compact structure [37]. The representatives of transition metals, cobalt and nickel, were used in the selective hydrogenation of CAL in this work, expected to acquire a high selectivity. As seen from Table 3 , addition of Co to Pt/CNTs brought about the increasing selectivity of COL up to 88.5%. This result agreed with the previous reports, which indicated that the addition of Co leaded to the acceleration of the activation of CO group. On the other hand, Ni-doped catalysts showed high selectivity in HCAL which demonstrated that the hydrogenation of the CC group was normally favored over Ni-doped catalysts. The promotion of selectivity was related to the nature of doped metal. Moreover, the selectivity of COL may depend up on the nature of the exposed crystal faces. It was observed that metal nanoparticles presented most the (111) surface in the Co-doped catalyst and Ni-doped catalyst showed partly the (200) surface (Fig. S3). Generally, the PtM(111) surface is compact and prefers the adsorption of the CO bond, resulting in high selectivity to COL. The open PtM(200) surface offers the nearly equivalent opportunity that the CC and CO bond access to the metal surface, which leads to the formation of HCAL [37,38]. Among the catalysts tested, the good conversion was still observed in the presence of functionalized catalysts. Though oxygen-functionalized catalyst also showed the good conversion, a large amount of HCOL was produced. So, the nitrogen-functionalized catalyst, especially PtCo/N-CNTs, was selected as the optimal catalyst in the following studies. Additionally, the functionalized bimetallic catalysts showed poorer selectivity of unsaturated product than unfunctionalized catalysts after Co and Ni doping. This is because the functionalized bimetallic catalysts had strong activity, which promoted the further hydrogenation at the high temperature, decreasing the selectivity of unsaturated product. Therefore, it is guessed that the functionalized bimetallic catalysts would show high activity and excellent selectivity even at the low temperature. In order to verify the guess, the temperature effect on the CAL reaction the optimal PtCo/N-CNTs catalyst was studied and the results are given in Fig. 7 a. Wu et al. [39] reported the conversion could reached 40% at 25°C after reaction for 2h, when Pt3Co-alloy nanoparticles was used as efficient catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of CAL. In this work, it could be seen that 52.1 % conversion was achieved at 20°C just after 1.5h (Fig. 7a). This implied that the PtCo/N-CNTs remained high activity even at the low temperature. The conversion was improved significantly with temperature increase during the lower temperature and reached 94.2% at the temperature of 40°C. The higher selectivity was achieved at a lower temperature. Elevating the temperature to 70°C, the selectivity to COL slightly decreased and the undesired HCOL selectivity increased. It was concluded the COL was a less thermodynamically stable product although a desired one and prone to transform into HCOL under high temperature. To further elevate the temperature to 80°C, the COL selectivity really decreased to 84.7%, while the quantity of HCOL remarkably increased to 11.8%. It was more difficult to achieve high selectivity to COL under high temperature. According to aforementioned temperature effect, the experiments were performed at the temperature of 40°C to research the effect of hydrogen pressure. It was obviously the hydrogen pressure could influence activity to a certain extent, but had little effect on product selectivity. This was because high pressure could enhance hydrogen solubility, which improved the opportunity that hydrogen molecules accessed to the substrate in the reaction medium [5]. However the improvement was paralleled for the CO bond and CO bond, resulting in the constant selectivity. As observed, the conversion increased with the hydrogen pressure increase from 0.5 to 1.5MPa (Fig. 7b). To further elevate the temperature, the hydrogen dissolution reached saturation and hydrogen transport was limited, resulting in no obvious conversion increase. 4 Conclusions The graphite structure of the CNTs was functionalized by ammonia and hydrogen peroxide without significant damage. The functionalization not merely increased the density of the N and O element but also dramatically modified its surface functional groups, which significantly promoted the content of metal nanoparticles and lead to the small size distribution of Pt particles on the CNT surface. The N and O species increased the distribution of positively charged Pt(II) and Pt(IV) species, which favors the activation of carbonyl group. The functionalized CNTs showed a great promotion in the conversion of hydrogenation reaction. However, the presence of the functionalization, especially for oxygen-functionalization, in the final catalyst was detrimental to the selective hydrogenation of CAL to COL in long reaction time. The addition of transition metals, cobalt, into the Pt catalyst significantly increased the selectivity of COL. The research of effects of temperature over PtCo/N-CNTs showed the high conversion and selectivity was obtained over PtCo/N-CNTs catalyst even at a low temperature. Thus, a highly active catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of CAL could be obtained by supporting Pt-based nanoparticles on nitrogen-functionalized CNTs, suggesting a new route for the preparation of high-performance catalysts by modifying the surface groups of the CNTs support. Acknowledgement The authors gratefully acknowledge financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 21203113). Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apcata.2015.08.023. coredata.dc:description: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) supported Pt catalysts were employed to study the influence of nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized surface on catalytic performance in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized CNTs were simply treated with the hydrothermal method using ammonia and hydrogen peroxide, respectively, and the metal catalyst was prepared using an impregnation-reduction-deposition method. Here, we studied and gave some insights into the influence of the functionalization on CNTs surface chemistry environment and Pt nanoparticles using XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TEM, XPS, and nitrogen sorption techniques. It was shown that the functionalization lead to the small size distribution of Pt particles and promoted the conversion from ca. 75% to ca. 95%. To obtain the high selectivity, transition metals, cobalt and nickel, were doped into the Pt catalyst and the 99.7% conversion with the 87.9% selectivity was achieved over the nitrogen-functionalized CNTs supported PtCo catalysts. The PtCo/N-CNTs remained high activity even at 40°C and achieved 94.2% conversion and 90.3% selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized carbon nanotubes supported Pt-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde
